definition:
Let $R$ be a ring. The **(right) weak global dimension** of $R$ is
defined as
$$\mathrm{w.gl.dim}R=\mathrm{sup}\{\mathrm{wd}_RM\ |\ M\mbox{ is a right module}\}.$$

Unlike global dimension of $R$ the definition of the weak global
dimension is left/right symmetric. This follows from the fact that for
every left module $M$ and right module $N$ there is an isomorphism
$$\mathrm{Tor}_n^R(M,N)\simeq\mathrm{Tor}_n^R(N,M).$$ Thus we simply say
that $R$ has the weak global dimension. Note that this does not hold for
Ext functors, so (generally) the definition of global dimension is not
left/right symmetric.

The following proposition is a simple consequence of the fact that every
projective module is flat:

**Proposition.** For any ring $R$ we have
$$\mathrm{w.gl.dim}R\leqslant\mathrm{min}\ \{\ \mathrm{l.gl.dim}R,\ \mathrm{r.gl.dim}R\ \},$$
where $\mathrm{l.gl.dim}$ and $\mathrm{r.gl.dim}$ denote the left global
dimension and right global dimension respectively.
